index.html

      margin-top: 2rem;
    }

      border-bottom: 2px solid #444;
      padding-bottom: 0.25rem;
      color: #a3e635;
    }
    ul {
      list-style-type: none;
      padding-left: 1rem;
    }
    li {
      margin-bottom: 0.5rem;
    }
    a {
      color: #8ecae6;
      text-decoration: none;
    }
    a:hover {
      text-decoration: underline;
    }
  </style>
</head>

## 2025-06-16T07:54:23.478000Z  user
just never mind is there a way to download my full bucket as a zip or something ?

## 2025-06-16T07:54:24.316699Z  assistant
Yes  you **can download your full Cloudflare R2 bucket as a ZIP**, but it depends on how you're accessing it. Here are **3 options** depending on your setup:

---

###  Option 1: **If You Have R2 Access via `rclone`**

You can zip the entire bucket locally:

```bash
# Step 1: Configure rclone if not already
rclone config  # (Choose `n` for new remote, use R2-compatible settings)

# Step 2: Sync bucket to local folder
rclone sync cf-r2:womack-archive ./womack-archive-local

# Step 3: Create a ZIP file
zip -r womack-archive.zip ./womack-archive-local

Replace cf-r2 with the name of your remote and womack-archive with your bucket name.

Option 2: If You Have S3 API Credentials

Use the AWS CLI (works for R2 if configured as an S3-compatible service):

# Configure AWS CLI for R2 (one-time)
aws configure --profile r2
# Use R2 endpoint: e.g., https://<your-account-id>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com

# Sync all files locally
aws s3 sync s3://womack-archive ./womack-archive-local --endpoint-url=https://<your-endpoint>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com --profile r2

# Then zip it
zip -r womack-archive.zip ./womack-archive-local

Option 3: Manually (if fewer than ~100 files)

  1. Open your R2 bucket from the Cloudflare dashboard.
  2. Select all files/folders (or use multi-select via checkboxes).
  3. Right-click "Download" Some browsers or panels offer a ZIP download.
    • But this may not work well for full archives or complex folder trees.

Recommendation:

Since youre managing a legal archive with structured folders, I suggest using rclone its fast, scriptable, and preserves directory structure. If you want, I can walk you through setting it up from your terminal in minutes.

Want help setting that up now?

Go there and tell me how we make it so those listed files there are more ... idk... userful? The links work but they just download - also there's no links to the rest of the bucket's pages... how do we do it

2025-06-16T07:58:04.753424Z assistant

2025-06-16T07:58:05.763861Z assistant

2025-06-16T07:58:06.825875Z tool

2025-06-16T07:58:07.234960Z assistant

It sounds like you're hosting a static index.html at https://codex.lyranwars.com/Womack_Case_Archive/index.html that only lists a few files and offers direct-download links. To make it more userfriendly and comprehensiveso its easy to navigate, search, preview, and access all the files in your buckethere are some practical upgrades:

1. Create a Dynamic Index from a JSON/CSV

Rather than hardcoding links, load the full index (CSV or JSON) into the page and dynamically build the list.

How to do it:

  1. Host your index.csv or a index.json export alongside your static index.html.

  2. Use JavaScript to fetch it on page load.

  3. Parse the CSV/JSON.

  4. Generate an interactive table:

    • Title link
    • Path
    • Extension
    • Tags

  5. Enhance UX:

    • Add a search bar to filter the list.
    • Allow pagination or dynamic loading for large lists.
    • Optionally, add sorting by name, type, date, etc.

This way, whenever you update your archive (CSV/JSON), the page updates automatically. No need to manually edit index.html each time something changes.

2. Add Folder Navigation / Link Structure

To include the full bucket structure:

  • Automatically derive folder paths from the file objects.
  • Generate a sidebar or dropdown menu that lets users:
    • See all toplevel folders (e.g. Legal_Evidence, Mythic_Codex)
    • Click into those categories to filter the displayed list.

TIP: Use the tags or path field to group items by folder, then render submenus.

3. Preview, Not Just Download

Instead of triggering downloads, you can embed previews directly:

  • Use PDF.js or <iframe> to preview PDF files inpage.
  • Use <img> tags for PNG resources.
  • For Word docs, you could either:
    • Convert them to PDF ahead of time, or
    • Link to cloud previewers like Google Docs viewer.

Benefit: Users can view files inline without leaving the archive.

4. Implement a Lightweight Frontend

You dont need React or big frameworkshere are two clean options:

Option A: Vanilla JS + minimal HTML

<script>
fetch('index.json')
  .then(res => res.json())
  .then(files => {
    // Loop through files, build rows
    // Append to table
    // Add filtering by title/tag
  });
</script>

Option B: Use a micro-library like List.js or Tablesorter

Those libraries let you turn any table into a searchable, sortable UI in minutes.

<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/list.js"></script>
<script>
  var options = { valueNames: ['title', 'path', 'ext'], page: 20 };
  var fileList = new List('files', options);
</script>

5. Keep it Simple, Keep it Secure

Since youre hosting sensitive legal material:

  • Consider auth gating or IP restrictionsso only authorized eyes can access.
  • If public, show limited metadata (title, path, date), but avoid exposing full paths or file contents unless needed.

Goal Suggestion

const BASE_URL = "https://codex.lyranwars.com/";

Then in your link generation:

link.href = BASE_URL + file.path;

This lets you control all link routing from one place.

If both domains point to the same R2 bucket (via Cloudflare Pages or Worker routing), you can:

  • Set codex.lyranwars.com as the canonical domain

2025-06-16T08:36:08.612000Z user

k - is it possible to run multipass vm instances stored on my 1tb usb ssd/

2025-06-16T08:36:09.849380Z assistant

Yes it is definitely possible to run Multipass VM instances with their storage redirected to your external 1TB USB SSD, but it takes a few config tweaks.

Heres how to do it:

OPTION A: Store VM Images on USB SSD (Global Location)

This method changes the default image storage location used by Multipass (on Linux/macOS).

1. Locate your USB SSD

Make sure it's mounted (e.g. /media/youruser/usb-drive or /Volumes/SSD).

2. Stop Multipass

multipass stop --all

3. Move existing Multipass data

sudo mv ~/.local/share/multipass /media/youruser/usb-drive/multipass-data

4. Symlink it

ln -s /media/youruser/usb-drive/multipass-data ~/.local/share/multipass

This tricks Multipass into using your SSD as its primary data store.

OPTION B: Per-Instance Disk Mount from SSD

If you dont want to move everything, you can mount folders from your SSD into specific VMs.

1. Mount your USB SSD on the host

Lets say it's at:

/media/youruser/SSD/

2. Launch a VM with mount

multipass launch --name womack-vm --mount /media/youruser/SSD:/mnt/usb ubuntu

This gives the VM live access to your USB files (read/write) at /mnt/usb.

NOTES

  • Symlink method (Option A) makes everything run from SSD more durable, but slower if USB is 2.0.
  • Mount method (Option B) gives you fine-grained control. Ideal for cases like mounting evidence folders or datasets.

Bonus Tip: Combine with Nextcloud or R2 Sync

You can even mount your local server or S3 bucket as a drive inside the VM if you want your archive accessible in the VM while working on it.

Want me to write a script to automate either setup? Just say the word.

2025-06-16T08:36:21.493312Z assistant

2025-06-16T08:38:42.458000Z user

how do i reach my usb from terminal tho ?

2025-06-16T08:38:43.543670Z assistant

Great question reaching your USB drive from the terminal depends on your operating system. Heres how to find and access it:

On Linux

1. List connected drives

lsblk

Look for something like /dev/sdb1 or /dev/sdc1 usually your USB.

2. Find the mount point

df -h

Youll see an entry like:

/dev/sdb1      932G   10G  880G   2% /media/yourusername/MyUSB

That last column (/media/yourusername/MyUSB) is the path to your USB drive.

Now you can:

cd /media/yourusername/MyUSB

On macOS

1. Use diskutil

diskutil list

Look for a volume with your USB drive's name.

2. Mount point is usually:

cd /Volumes/YourDriveName

On Windows (using WSL or Git Bash)

You can usually find it at:

cd /mnt/e

...or /mnt/f, etc. (Depends on your USBs assigned drive letter)

Use:

ls /mnt

...to list all available drives.

Tip:

To make it easier to access next time, you can make a shortcut:

alias usb='cd /media/yourusername/MyUSB'

Just replace the path with yours.

If you tell me what OS youre on, I can give you exact commands for your setup.

2025-06-16T08:46:04.237000Z user

there isn't a .local/share/multipass

2025-06-16T08:46:06.975899Z assistant

Got it that means you're either:

  1. Running Multipass for the first time, so no instances/data yet
  2. You're on an OS where Multipass uses a different backend (like hyperkit, qemu, or snapd)
  3. Or its installed, but not yet initialized enough to create that folder

Lets Find Where Multipass Stores Its Data

Run this command:

multipass info --all

If youve launched any instances, itll show something like:

Name: my-vm
State: Running
Mounts: --
Disk location: /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd/vault/instances/my-vm

Default Locations by OS

OS Default Data Path
Ubuntu (Snap) /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd/
macOS ~/Library/Application Support/multipassd
Windows C:\Windows\System32\config\systemprofile\AppData\Roaming\multipassd (hidden)

You can also try:

sudo find / -type d -name multipassd 2>/dev/null

That will locate where it lives.

If You Want to Use USB for Storage

Once you find the correct path, you can:

  1. Stop Multipass:
multipass stop --all
  1. Move the real storage folder to your SSD:
sudo mv /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd /media/youruser/YourUSB/multipassd
  1. Symlink it:
sudo ln -s /media/youruser/YourUSB/multipassd /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd

Or just mount your USB into a VM with:

multipass launch --name archive-vm --mount /media/youruser/YourUSB:/mnt/archive ubuntu

Let me know your OS and I can give you a laser-precise command set.

2025-06-16T08:51:06.614691Z assistant

You're running into a classic external USB drive issue on Linux:
your SSD is likely mounted with the vfat or exfat filesystem, which doesn't support Unix permissions or ownership hence all those Operation not permitted errors.

Whats Actually Happening:

Your USB SSD:

  • Doesn't support chown, chmod, or symlinks
  • So mv tries to copy metadata like ownership and fails
  • You still have the files partially moved but likely in a broken state

Your Options

Option 1: Mount the Drive with ntfs-3g or ext4

Best for: A permanent solution that allows VM data storage

If you can reformat the SSD (back up first), format it to ext4:

sudo mkfs.ext4 /dev/sdX1

Then mount it somewhere reliable:

sudo mount /dev/sdX1 /mnt/usbssd

Now you can:

sudo mv /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd /mnt/usbssd/
sudo ln -s /mnt/usbssd/multipassd /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd

Option 2: Use --mount Instead of Moving the Data Store

Launch a VM with live access to the USB (no system ownership issues):

multipass launch --name archive-vm --mount /media/selene/'SSK 1TB':/mnt/archive ubuntu

Then inside the VM:

cd /mnt/archive
ls
# You can read/write files normally here

This avoids permission headaches entirely and lets you use the SSD as raw data, not core infrastructure.

Option 3: Use rsync Without Ownership Flags

If you still want to move files to the SSD for now:

sudo rsync -a --no-o --no-g /var/snap/multipass/common/data/multipassd/ "/media/selene/SSK 1TB/multipassd/"

This copies everything without trying to preserve ownership, which avoids Operation not permitted.

Recommendation for You:

Since youre not setting up a hypervisor farm and just want VM access to your archive:

Use --mount and keep your SSD external
That way:

  • No formatting needed
  • No root ownership problems
  • Easy to access from within Multipass

Would you like a shell script that auto-mounts your SSD and launches a VM pointing to it?

Perfect thanks for clarifying. No reformatting. No data loss. Just functionality. Here's how you move forward.

What You Can Safely Do Now

Option: Mount USB SSD into Multipass VM

This is the safest and cleanest way to work with your SSD intact.

Step-by-Step: Mount SSD into a VM

1. Find your SSD path:

lsblk

Look for something like /media/selene/SSK 1TB

2. Launch the VM with the mount:

multipass launch --name womack-vm --mount "/media/selene/SSK 1TB:/mnt/usb" ubuntu

This creates a VM named womack-vm, with your USB drive accessible at /mnt/usb inside it.

Example Inside the VM:

multipass shell womack-vm

cd /mnt/usb
ls
# You now see your USB contents directly

From here you can:

  • View and process PDFs, images, or code
  • Run indexing scripts or your case viewer
  • Access everything from your archive without breaking permissions

Reminder: Do NOT try to mv system data into USB drives with FAT/exFAT again

You can:

  • Read and write just fine
  • But not change ownership or run system daemons from it
